TLINE.TDLINE: &USE&
The communication between applications of different systems in the SAP
environment can include both the connection between SAP systems and also
between SAP and non-SAP systems. The Remote Function Call (RFC) is the
SAP standard interface for implementing this communication. The RFC
calls a function to be executed in a remote system.
&PRECONDITIONS&
&STANDARD_SETUP&
&ACTIVITY&
Synchronous RFC
The first version of the RFC is the synchronous RFC (sRFC). This RFC
type performs the call of a function based on the synchronous
communication, i. The systems involved must both be accessible at the
time of the call.
Asynchronous RFC (aRFC)
Despite its name, the aRFC is not a real asynchronous communication type
because it only fulfills the conditions for this. For example, As with
the sRFC, the called system will be available during the call.
The aRFC has the following main features:
The function control returns to the calling program immediately after
the call.
The parameters of asynchronous RFCs are not written to the database but
passed directly to the server.
During an asynchronous RFC, the user can perform a dialog with the
remote system.
When the caller starts an aRFC, the called server must be available to
accept the request.
The calling program can receive results of asynchronous RFCs.
The use of the aRFC is always useful when a real-time communication is
established with a remote system, but the processing in the calling
program is not to be interrupted until the results of the called
function module are present (the term asynchronous is here in this sense
used).
